newsitem.title: JAPAN: DirecTV to launch satellite broadcasting in Japan.
newsitem.headline: DirecTV to launch satellite broadcasting in Japan.

text.p: DirecTV Japan Inc, a group company of Hughes Electronics Corp of the United States, said on Tuesday that it would start a digital satellite broadcasting service in Japan in autumn 1997.

DirecTV will become the third digital satellite broadcasting company to start broadcasting in Japan after PerfecTV, which is owned by a consortium headed by trading company Itochu Corp, and J-SkyB, which is due to be launched next April.
J-SkyB is a venture between Australian media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's News Corp Ltd and Japan's Softbank Corp.
PerfecTV launched its service earlier this month.
A statement from DirecTV did not say exactly when in the autumn of 1997 its service would be launched.
Michael Armstrong, chairman of Hughes Electronics, said DirecTV would differentiate itself from two other services by offering a higher quality service and competitive pricing.
"We have experience in the United States," he told a news conference. "We came to the U.S. market second ... and today we have two million subscribers."
Armstrong also said DirecTV would join a study group to develop a common receiver if the government agreed.
Such receivers would allow users to access broadcasting services provided by the three firms. Murdoch has said he hopes to tie up with PerfecTV by sharing a receiver.
It also said that Mitsubishi Corp and Mitsubishi Electric Co 6503 T had each acquired a five percent stake in DirecTV, raising its total capitalisation to 10.3 billion yen.
Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, Dai Nippon Printing Co, and the Mitsubishi group's satellite company Satellite Communications Corp (SCC) already own stakes in DirecTV.
DirecTV said it would launch its 100-channel service using SCC's Superbird C communications satellite, which will be launched in June 1997.
